For the purpose of this question, 'confirmed cases' refers to laboratory-confirmed mpox infections as defined by the reporting health authority.

title: Will the Central African Republic declare its mpox outbreak contained by July 2024?
body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Central African Republic officially declares that its current mpox outbreak is contained. The declaration must come from the Central African Republic's Ministry of Health or a reputable international health organization such as the World Health Organization (WHO). The declaration should explicitly state that the outbreak is 'contained,' 'controlled,' or use similar terminology indicating that the spread has been effectively halted. For the purpose of this question, 'contained' means that new cases have significantly decreased and the outbreak is no longer considered a major public health threat in the country. If no such declaration is made by the specified date, or if the outbreak is still ongoing, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question specifically refers to the outbreak declared in 2023 and does not apply to any potential future outbreaks that may occur after October 1, 2023.

title: Will the Federal Reserve implement at least two interest rate cuts by July 2024?
body:
This question will resolve as YES if the Federal Reserve officially announces and implements at least two interest rate cuts by July 31, 2024. For the purpose of this question:

1. An 'interest rate cut' refers to a reduction in the federal funds rate target range set by the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC).
2. The cuts must be distinct events, not a single larger cut split into two parts.
3. The implementation of both cuts must occur on or before July 31, 2024.
4. Confirmation of the rate cuts must come from official Federal Reserve communications, such as FOMC statements or press releases.
5. In the absence of direct Federal Reserve confirmation, reports from at least three major financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC) will be considered sufficient for verification.

If fewer than two rate cuts are announced and implemented by the resolution date, or if no cuts occur at all, the question resolves as NO.

This question will resolve as YES if the trial of Alec Baldwin, related to the shooting incident on the set of the film 'Rust' that resulted in the death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, concludes with a final verdict by July 31, 2024. For resolution purposes:

1. The trial must have officially begun and reached a conclusion with a verdict.
2. The conclusion of the trial must be officially reported by the court where the trial is taking place.
3. The verdict must be reported by at least two reputable national or international news sources (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, CNN, New York Times).

If the trial does not conclude, is delayed beyond the specified date, or if no verdict is reached by July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

Note: This question does not consider potential appeals or subsequent legal proceedings that may occur after the initial trial verdict.

The dismissal must be confirmed by official court records and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). If the trial proceeds or is not dismissed by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For clarity, 'dismissal' refers to the court formally terminating the legal proceedings against Baldwin before a verdict is reached, not including temporary suspensions or delays in the trial process.

body:

The question resolves as NO if no such claim is filed or if there is insufficient evidence of a claim being filed by the resolution date.

Note that appeals, settlements, or partial payments totaling less than $4 billion will also result in a NO resolution.

title: Will a U.S. federal agency announce regulatory changes in response to a recent Supreme Court ruling by July 2024?
body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, any U.S. federal agency officially announces changes to its existing regulations as a direct result of the Supreme Court ruling concerning challenges to long-standing regulations. The announcement must: 1) Be made through official channels of the federal agency (e.g., press release, official website, or public statement by agency leadership). 2) Explicitly state that the changes are in response to or influenced by the Supreme Court's decision regarding challenges to regulations. 3) Be reported by at least two reputable national news sources (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Washington Post). The question will resolve as NO if no such announcement meeting all the above criteria is made by the specified date. Changes to internal agency procedures that do not affect existing regulations do not qualify for a YES resolution.
